title: Sidewall, 1920–30
description: An assortment of wallpapers some of which appear to be French. Varied subject matter. Strong color. Diagonals and stylized foliage. Samples -h/j are children's papers.
gallery_text: This charming landscape scene is full of the energy and optimism of the 1920s. Landscape scenes used as motifs in wallpaper designs have been around since the late 18th century but have been changed stylistically to evolve with the current trends. The bold pattern and coloring reflects the optimism of the post-war period. This design is an inexpensive wallpaper machine-printed in four colors. The bright orange background color and hills give the design a rather surreal quality, keeping it lighthearted, and distancing itself from more realistic landscape renderings. Being machine-printed means all the colors are printed on the paper in one pass through the printing machine, necessitating that the colors be thin so they dry quickly. This aspect of the production works very well for this design, softening the trees somewhat so they appear less harsh against the very bold ground color.

tombstone.epitaph: Sidewall, 1920–30. machine-printed on paper. Gift of Charles Grimmer & Son. 1930-14-1-k.
